Name: Salad King
About information: Thai eatery serving noodles, curries & salads, with communal tables & a choice of spice levels.
Customer reviews:
-We went to Salad King after many years and the food brought back so many memories. The food is amazing and we both got the Thai Islamic Noodles. Service is fast and very efficient, but we always feel rushed there. Their turnover of customers is always so quick. Mind you, it is a student spot so this makes sense. Regardless, this restaurant has the best Thai food and it is well worth it!
-Salad king is my favourite Thai place in Toronto! It is affordable (an effort they do to make the students from TMU be able to buy food from here),incredibly delicious and very well-portioned. The trifecta of food when eating out.I went out with by boyfriend and our mothers. They both got the battered shrimp fried rice with sweet chili oil, my bf got the panang curry and I get my signature: chicken Siam noodles. We all had to take our food home because of the amount of food that we got. For the 20$ you will pay,it is worth it. Please visit this place it is a downtown staple!

Name: Jack's Dundas Square
About information: Hey - we're Jack Astor's. Our mission? Great people helping other great people totally have a blast while enjoying amazing food. We specialize in delicious food and drink and are a lot like a reverse mullet- we're a party in the front and all business in the back. In all seriousness though, we take real pride in our food and make over 200 recipes in house - Every. Single. Day. Mic drop. Try our fresh guacamole, centre cut aged Canadian AAA striploins or our famous Jack's Chicken Fingers, made with fresh never frozen seasoned chicken tenders, hand breaded to order. We also sling an impressive selection of craft brews and cocktails. So let your hair down, loosen your belt and come hangout!
Customer reviews:
-Jack Astor's provided an okay dining experience, with the food meeting expectations. The environment was pleasant, contributing to an overall enjoyable visit. While the food didn't stand out, the agreeable atmosphere added to the positive aspects of the dining experience.
-Loved their mexican chicken bowl it was so flavourful and yummy. A 10/10 recommendation. Street style chicken tacos were also very tasty. Just one thing please make sure you check on your customers as we had to call her everytime we need something she would’ve just checked on herself.

Name: Fran's Restaurant
About information: Part of a local chain, this venerable spot serves sandwiches, steaks & burgers at all hours.
Customer reviews:
-Stopped in for lunch. Never been to this location but if was anything like the other then it should be good! Wait staff attentive and friendly. Many of the customers the staff knew by name l. I ordered a strawberry shake to start. It arrived in the stainless cup, but was not full, I would have expected there to be more but after trying it, the taste made me focus less on the quantity and more so on the deliciousness! I ordered fish & chips and my lunch arrived very quickly. Two sizeable pieces of haddock which I was impressed with. Very good batter, crispy like how I like it. Thick as well. Fries were good with some malt vinegar and the coleslaw was perfect, creamy and as if they just shredded it. A very good experience and the staff were excellent, dropping by my table to ensure if everything was  to my liking. I’ll definitely be back.
-met a friend for lunch here today and the restaurant was lively. even with most of the tables filled up and staff moving around constantly, a server kindly greeted and welcomed me. noticed that the service was generally pretty quick, which was great since we were on a bit of a time crunch. i ordered fran’s energy breakfast and my friend got the nachos please (added homemade chili). i didn’t get to try my friend’s order (again, we were in a rush), but my meal was alright. the egg was big, but the slice of ham was very thin (could barely taste it) and the homemade fries were mid (not the best i’ve ever had). overall, the service was great (attentive and energetic, despite how busy and chaotic it was), but i probably won’t order the same meal again (for that price at least).

Name: Paramount Middle Eastern Kitchen
About information: Lively Middle Eastern place serving barbecued halal meats, house-baked pitas & baklava made on-site.
Customer reviews:
-Very nice place to eat, if you are in downtown and looking for a different taste. The food was delicious we tried the chicken shawarma and the garlic bread was so good. This is the place if you want to try some middle eastern food in Toronto downtown. The service was nice and quick we didn't wait too long for our orders and the waitress was very friendly. The atmosphere was good with middle eastern music which we loved. Highly recommended for food lovers who enjoy experiencing new flavors
-Delicious food at a very reasonable cost for the area! If you’re looking for authentic Middle Eastern, this is definitely worth a try. The falafel is perfectly crispy on the outside and perfectly smooth on the inside. The hummus is velvety smooth and the pita is hot and fluffy when it arrives. The servers were prompt and friendly and the atmosphere is casual but classy. Plus lots of vegetarian options to choose without sacrificing flavour!

Name: Five Guys
About information: Fast-food chain with made-to-order burgers, fries & hot dogs, plus free peanuts while you wait.
Customer reviews:
-Always a treat. Service is friendly and quick.  Great burger joint.
This time around I had the bacon cheese burger (2 beef patties) (everything on it) with fries & gravy.  I was offered a drink but passed.  Had a craving for milk but sadly it's not available.  They do have shakes though. The gravy is on point.  Sticks to your fries and has a good flavour.
-When the urge for a burger strikes, Five Guys is the go-to spot. While you wait, enjoy complimentary peanuts, and discover the daily source of their fresh potato produce

Name: Chelsea Hotel, Toronto
About information:
This relaxed hotel in a high-rise building is a 4-minute walk from Ryerson University, 2 km from the Royal Ontario Museum and 3 km from the CN Tower.
Casual rooms offer flat-screen TVs and free Wi-Fi; some include balconies and/or views of the CN Tower. Studios have kitchenettes; suites add separate living areas. Club level rooms have access to a lounge serving free continental breakfast and snacks.
Amenities include an informal restaurant, a coffee shop and a cozy bar. There's also a 27th-floor indoor pool with an outdoor sundeck featuring city views, plus a waterslide, a fitness centre and saunas.
Customer reviews:
-Rooms are clean, but dated.  Bed was very cozy and comfy. Pillows are the best! Lovely shower with great water pressure.  Having a balcony was a treat, and I really enjoyed the views of the city during the day and especially the lights at night. Great downtown location.  Thanks for offering a discount for hospital stays and for extending it to include inside parking as well.
-The staff at the Chelsea Hotel were excellent,  from booking, until check-out.  We required some special help which was offered without reservation.   Staff went out of their way to ensure our comfort and contentment.   Second visit was equally good.   We had left something behind on our first visit which they quickly located and delivered to our room.  The Health club was in excellent condition as well.   Most of all it was the outgoing staff who made these visits memorable. Cheers to you all!

Name: Filmores Hotel
About information:
Adjacent to the light rail tracks, this straightforward hotel is a mile from the Art Gallery of Ontario and 1.9 miles from the Ripley's Aquarium of Canada.
The down-to-earth rooms have traditional furnishings and come with cable TV and separate sitting areas. Room service is also available.
Amenities include a coin-operated laundry and a tanning salon.
Customer reviews:
-Extremely basic, which was reflected in price. However, my room had an ensuite, queen bed, and was very spacious.
Despite having a dated decor, the staff still done an excellent job of cleaning. My room was spotless on arrival. Good job team.
Finally, Jessica and Jelissa were always smiling and happy to help with anything I needed during my stay.
All in, reasonably priced for its location.
-The staff here are great, you need to know under the hotel there is a strip club. The dancers do pass through the hotel so be respectful. The music from the club does go into the rooms though it's silent after 2 AM, I would stay here again.

Name: Pantages Hotel Downtown Toronto
About information:
A 2-minute walk from shopping at Toronto Eaton Centre, this all-suite hotel in a high-rise is a 7-minute drive from the CN tower's revolving eatery.
Luxe suites featuring contemporary decor and furnishings include floor-to-ceiling windows, rainfall showerheads, flat-screen TVs and WiFi, as well as kitchenettes. Upgraded suites have separate living rooms and washer/dryers.
A chic martini bar off the lobby has a menu of upscale bar food and live music on the weekends. Freebies include a fitness centre, a relaxation room with sauna, whirlpool and steam room, plus a business centre. A Japanese spa offers treatments for a fee.
Customer reviews:
-This hotel is a little dated, but you cannot beat its location.  We had the studio suite on the top floor, and the view was wonderful, especially on a clear, sunny, blue winter day.  It was the perfect for a night around town and it was great to return to the room after a late performance at a theatre nearby.
-Had a great stay here. Spacious and clean room, tastefully decorated. Off of the main street so it was quiet. Only complaint was the TV; can’t use any streaming services, only cable and movies to order.

Name: Holiday Inn Toronto Downtown Centre, an IHG Hotel
About information:
Less than a block from College subway station, this high-rise hotel is also a 9-minute walk from shopping at the Eaton Centre.
Modern rooms come with flat-screen TVs and desks, plus minifridges and coffeemakers. Kids 19 and under stay free with an adult and there's free WiFi in every room, as well as a choice of hard and soft pillows. Suites add separate living spaces and kitchenettes.
The facility also offers a restaurant (where kids 12 and under eat free), an indoor pool and an exercise room, plus a rooftop patio and paid parking.
Customer reviews:
-I was on the 12th floor and they upgraded me to a junior suite. It was nice and well appointed. Reasonable size. I had the buffet breakfast included in the room cost. It was a typical breakfast buffet with lots of selection. Parking on site but if you have a large truck you may not fit. The area is a concrete jungle but that isn't bad if you have business in the area or are going to one of the hospitals or U of T.
-Parking and check in were great, staff were pleasant, helpful and friendly. We had a room with 2 double beds it was kind of small for 4 guests and the pool was cool not that warm.  Buffet was amazing and it is so close to everything.  We walked to all our attractions and then 12 dollar left ride back to the hotel.  Enjoyed it all

Name: Holiday Inn Express Toronto Downtown
About information:
A 9-minute walk from King subway station, this laid-back lodging is also 2.1 km from the landmark CN Tower and Ripley's Aquarium of Canada.
Straightforward rooms come with flat-screen TVs, desks and coffeemakers, plus free WI-Fi. Kids 19 and under stay free with an adult.
A free breakfast buffet is offered. There's a gym and a business centre. Parking is available for a fee.
Customer reviews:
-We requested an early check-in, but they couldn't guarantee anything until we arrived. When arriving, they mentioned our original room wasn't ready, but they quickly found us another room that was available.

We stayed on the 12th floor. The room was nice and clean. The mini fridge wasn't working, but the room had a nice view of downtown.

The breakfast was decent. They offered the usual: scrambled eggs, pork sausage, turkey sausage, yogurt, cereal, etc.

Overall, it's a good place for a quick few nights.
-Comfortable beds and bedding, loved different pillow options. Easy to use temperature gage. Also, great sound proofing, I did not hear other guests during my stay. I was able to rest but also explore the city, the hotel is in a great location.

Name: Adventure City Games Toronto - Old Toronto
About information: Escape room center
Customer reviews:
-Fun way to see the city. The puzzles aren’t very challenging so no problem completing. Very easy to share clues among the group. We had two phones for 4 people.
-We had so much fun adventuring through Toronto! Such a great way to see the city and the puzzles were so fun and exciting. I’d highly recommend this to anyone looking to get outside and explore their city. We found so many places we never would’ve even known existed! 10/10 would highly recommend!

Name: Museum of Illusions Toronto
About information: Small museum with optical illusions & holograms for selfies, plus logic games & a vortex tunnel.
Customer reviews:
-Contrary to a traditional walk-through museum, this venue consisted of a medium-sized room with interconnected smaller rooms. Despite its compact layout, it still offered engaging interactive experiences and photo opportunities, albeit geared more towards children. Our visit, including exploring these spaces and capturing photos, lasted about 20 minutes.
-We booked this on their website for a Christmas Day at 10:00am. I was surprised that they were opened. When we went in there was 10 of us. We went from room to room taking pictures. The staff were as very friendly. They explained some of the illusions and took our picture. It took 45 minutes to get through. There was an area to do some puzzles. We ended up buying a few in the gift shop at the front of the store $16 each. There is a room where you can hang up your coat and leave your belongs but it's not their responsibility if something gets taken.
This was a great experience and I only wished it were bigger. But being that it's downtown I can understand their issue with the space.

Name: Toronto Music Garden
About information: Yo Yo Ma contributed to the design of this scenic garden with summer concerts & seasonal tours.
Customer reviews:
-The Toronto Music Garden is a hidden gem and a tranquil oasis in the heart of the city. This beautifully landscaped garden, inspired by Bach's music, is a harmonious blend of nature and art. Visitors can stroll along the winding paths, admiring the carefully designed plantings and sculptures that reflect musical compositions. It's a serene place to escape the urban hustle and bustle. The garden often hosts free music events during the summer, adding a delightful auditory dimension to the experience. Whether you're a music lover or just seeking a peaceful escape, the Toronto Music Garden is a lovely and unique destination that offers a respite for the soul.
-A must visit place all through summer, have lots of fun and enjoy good music from amateur artists, those in downtown on a short trip or live in the neighbourhood take out time to spend some quality time with friends and family. Encourage the young artists

Name: Little Canada
About information: Exhibit
Customer reviews:
-Very cool! I went with my almost 5-year old and we had a great time. I loved the amount of detail in the displays. My kid loved the moving parts, especially the trains and cars. The staff was very friendly and really excited to show us some of the Easter eggs in each of the exhibits. You can tell they enjoyed working there and liked talking to kids, which made our experience that much better. We'll definitely come back!
-I recently visited "Little Canada" and was absolutely mesmerized by this incredible attraction. The attention to detail and craftsmanship in every miniature scene is astounding. From the bustling streets of Toronto to the scenic vistas of Niagara, every aspect is crafted with remarkable precision and a love for detail.

This place is perfect for a family outing or for anyone looking to escape into a different world for a moment and experience all of Canada in one spot. "Little Canada" offers a unique experience that will leave a lasting impression. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Toronto.

Name: Art Gallery of Ontario
About information: Large gallery with huge Canadian collection, European masterworks & a major Frank Gehry renovation.
Customer reviews:
-Amazing museum. It was one of the best accessibility places I have visited. Never once did my wife's wheelchair have an issue once in the museum. Parking was bad. Would recommend not using the parking garage across the road from it if you need a wheelchair.

The art collection was beautiful. A lot of Canadian collections, great impressionist works, great female artist pieces, the special exhibits were amazing. I was just overwhelmed by the experience.
-Very large museum, but manageable in a few hours. It had a good variety of exhibits and artworks, from a range of cultures and styles. It is big enough to handle a large amount of people at any one time so you don’t feel crowded when inside. Additionally, under 25s go free which is wonderful for any younger people who wish to visit- no worries about cost! Also, the restaurant is good :)

Name: Blaze Pizza
About information: Hip counter-serve pizzeria dishing up crispy, thin-crust pies made with creative toppings & sauces.
Customer reviews:
-Took my long term partner here as we were getting a bit hungry on a chilly Toronto walk. The employee taking our order had a most welcome and almost encouraging attitude which allowed us to savor our food even more. The build your own pizza is a treat.
-Heard a lot about this place and when I went, I enjoyed the pizza. It was delicious and fresh. Try the garlic breads too when you are here.

Name: Ram in the Rye
About information: Casual sports bar in the the Ryerson Student Centre offering sports on the big screen & events.
Customer reviews:
-Amazing affordable food, tastes great and most importantly it's cheaper compared to everywhere else downtown. The servers here are also really nice :) love it. There are also many halal options!
-Great place for good food at a reasonable price and drinks to complement.

Name: Courtyard by Marriott Toronto Downtown
About information:
This informal hotel is less than a block from College subway station and a 9-minute walk from shopping at the Toronto Eaton Centre.
Contemporary rooms offer free WiFi, desks, flat-screen TVs and coffeemakers. Suites add separate living areas.
Social spaces include a living room-style lobby. The full-service American restaurant serves breakfast and dinner, while the bistro offers breakfast, lunch and dinner as well as all-day drinks, including Starbucks coffee. There's also a business centre and 19 meeting rooms, plus a 24-hour exercise room.
Customer reviews:
-The service was impeccable, with a friendly and attentive staff. The room was not only comfortable but also meticulously clean. The hotel’s central location made exploring the city effortless. From the stylish decor to the top-notch amenities, it was a truly five-star experience. I highly recommend this hotel for an exceptional stay in downtown Toronto.
-Excellent experience. Rooms were spotless, and the housekeeping team kept them pristine during our whole week-long trip. Plenty of space: fridge, dresser, closet, roomy bathroom. Linens and towels were fluffy and clean. Complimentary water and chocolates were a lovely touch! The continental breakfast was okay—I would skip and find something local instead; the selection wasn’t great. The hotel staff were sooo kind and were able to offer great local recommendations for things to do. Location is perfect—safe and easy to walk to many nearby neighborhoods. Ideal for those visiting the university or tourists looking to explore downtown.

Name: DoubleTree by Hilton Toronto Downtown
About information:
A mile from the landmark CN Tower, this relaxed hotel is 3 minutes' walk from St. Patrick's subway station and 8 minutes' walk from the Art Gallery of Ontario.
Streamlined rooms offer free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and coffeemakers; some have minifridges. Suites add separate living areas, and some include kitchens or whirlpool baths.
There's a casual bistro and a polished Asian eatery, along with a heated indoor pool, a sauna and a fitness centre. Other amenities include a 24-hour business centre and more than 13,000 sq ft of conference space.
Customer reviews:
-Overall not a bad stay. This hotel is in the perfect location, right beside Nathan Phillips Square and St. Patrick Station. The room was on the smaller side, but big windows made it feel nice and bright. Sadly a new tower has gone up right next door, which blocks any CN Tower views. Warm cookies at check-in is also a nice touch.
Unfortunately our stay was not perfect, as midway through my shower the water started coming out dark brown for about 20 seconds. The front-desk sent up their “engineering” team to have a look, who just told me to run the water for 5 minutes before using it. Considering this happened in the middle of my shower, I don’t see how that would help…
It didn’t completely ruin the stay for me, but there definitely shouldn’t be brown water coming out of the taps in a Hilton brand property…
-We had an amazing experenice staying at this hotel from beginning to end. We stayed 2 nights and everything went smooth. Staff was amazing and very helpful, room was well kept. Hotel was in good location, 2 min walking distance from Eaton Center.
I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for good service and a clean facility. 100 stars to the staff.

Name: Harbourfront Centre
About information: Lakeside cultural hub with dance, modern art, craft & theatre spaces, plus many annual events.
Customer reviews:
-A very beautiful beach and a long walk  along the beach may be a  memorable trip to everyone, enjoy boating, speed boating with family and friends. You may enjoy the beautiful view of CN Tower and the skyrise  buildings specially during evening.
-The center, which opened in 1974, is a stunning urban playground and one of the most popular destinations for locals and visitors alik and a great place to spend time strolling, picnicking, gallery-hopping, biking, shopping, and sailing. Harbourfront has several venues devoted to the arts. Underground parking is available on-site at 235 Queens Quay West, or above-ground one block west at Rees Street and Queens Quay West.

Name: Allan Gardens
About information: Collection of plants from around the world housed in a cast-iron & glass building dating from 1910.
Customer reviews:
-I can't find nicer words to explain how magical this place is! The staff is super helpful and really welcoming. Loved every second of this trip.

Don't hesitate to pay Allan Gardens a visit. Nobody could stay stressed inside. Just sit by the bridge and watch the water-wheel and turtles forever.
-Beautiful garden! Such a nice breath of fresh air in the city. The plants were all so well taken care of and vibrant. The volunteer was so helpful, giving us directions and letting us know where to find the different plants. The highlight for us was the turtles. There were so many!! We spent a solid ten minutes just admiring them. Will definitely be back!

Name: Katsuya
About information: Lively Japanese fusion joint specializing in breaded cutlets & other deep-fried eats, plus beer.
Customer reviews: -Katsuya's udon and pork loin katsu are both fantastic options that truly capture the essence of Japan. The udon noodles are wonderfully chewy, swimming in a rich and flavorful broth that instantly transports you to the streets of Tokyo. And the pork loin katsu? It's a masterpiece of crispy perfection, with succulent meat that practically melts in your mouth. Together, they create a culinary experience that's as authentic as it is delicious. Highly recommended for anyone craving a taste of Japan!                                                                                                                                     -I would highly recommend the red carbonara pork katsu dish. It was delicious. Huge portion. Very friendly attentive staff. We also had the cheese crabmeat croquette and the takoyaki.

Name: Yonge Suites
About information:
A 12-minute walk from the Financial District, this modern apartment hotel is adjacent to a shopping centre and a TTC Subway station. It's within a 6-minute walk of City Hall, Ryerson University and St. Michael's Hospital.
Airy, contemporary apartments feature hardwood floors, granite countertops, full kitchens, living areas and workspaces. All come with climate control and laundry facilities, in addition to free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and iPod docks. Many have floor-to-ceiling windows with city views. Loft-style penthouses offer wraparound terraces.
Meeting facilities are available.
Customer reviews: -I recently stayed at Yonge Suites and it was an excellent experience. The rooms were spacious and modern, with all the amenities I needed. The staff was friendly and helpful, and the breakfast was delicious. The hotel is conveniently located close to shopping and restaurants, and the area is very safe. I would highly recommend this hotel for anyone looking for a comfortable and enjoyable stay.                                                                                                                               -Hotel is dated. Service was good, they accommodated our last minute check in times at a very unsocial hour. Location was great, middle of the city and number of attractions metro/train station was walking distance

Name: CN Tower
About information: Landmark, over 553-metre tower featuring a glass floor & a revolving eatery with panoramic views.
Customer reviews:
-Great view!!! We came Monday 10:30, was almost no one there, took great pictures without the crowd. Bought tickets online in 2 minutes, very easy! Staff was also very nice and helpful.
Just be ready they going to check your bags, we are visitors from another city, they took out all clothes we had in the backpack, the good thing they were accurate to put it back.                                                                                                                                                          -One of the most touristic spots in Toronto. There is a wonderful view of the city from the top. Really beautiful. You go up to the top with the elevator, which is very fast. At night, the tower is illuminated and it is nice to observe it even from afar. It is usually very crowded, so you can expect a long queue, approx. at least an hour. There is also a souvenir shop in the tower. You can also walk on the glass floor, which is very exciting.

Name: Egg Club
About information: Straightforward takeaway dishing up egg sandwiches & BLTs with Japanese milk bread.
Customer reviews:
-I’m amazed I hadn’t discovered this place sooner! They offer an affordable breakfast menu priced between 6-10$ , featuring delicious hash browns and fantastic sandwiches. The service is quick, and the presentation is on point - absolutely loved it! A tip: order ahead to avoid waiting in the shop, as it can get a bit smelly with the scent of burnt eggs and bacon. Both the BLT and Egg Club sandwiches were amazing. Highly recommend!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         -I was excited to try the bacon egg sandwich as seen on TikTok with all the rave reviews.

Honestly I was not a fan at all of the sandwich. The special "egg club sauce" was wayyyyy to sweet. I think I would have liked it a lot more without the "special sauce". The sandwich was also pretty expensive for what it was. I would only try again if the sauce wasn't in it and the price doesn't increase any more.

Name: Neill Wycik Hotel
About information:
Occupying 17 floors in a high-rise student residence, this unassuming seasonal hotel is 2 km from both the Royal Ontario Museum and St. Lawrence Market South.
Straightforward dorms feature Wi-Fi, desks and shared bathrooms. Private rooms add en suite facilities.
Amenities include coin-operated laundry facilities, a communal kitchen, and a rooftop terrace with BBQs. Parking and breakfast are available.
Customer reviews: -Best value for price that I could find anywhere in downtown Toronto, I loved the fact that single rooms were available, as opposed to other hostels that require sharing a room with other people. I got my own bedroom that locked, and shared a toilet, shower, and large kitchen area (with a fridge and stove) with four or five other rooms. When I stayed, it was pretty quiet and there was only one other person in my suite. My only complaints are that the rooms were hot (but not unbearably so) and the sheets weren't the most comfortable, but overall you can't beat the location, price, and excellent service from the staff. Free breakfast is an amazing bonus - the selection was good and the amount of food you get is amazing! Other reviews might be overly critical because of the student dorm energy, but as a student myself who is used to living in residence, my room was very clean and the furniture was in surprisingly decent condition.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 -Fantastic location downtown. Stayed for two weeks with my husband and daughter in a quad room. The rooms are dorm style so don’t expect fancy and bring a fan because the rooms can get hot (we travel here with a tower fan). The roof top has amazing views of the city and there are 2 bbq on the roof. Be sure to travel with some basic dishes, pots, pans, and utensils if you plan to cook. This is our second year staying here and it’s a great affordable option.

Name: Nathan Phillips Square
About information: Lively public space in front of city hall hosting events year-round & a busy ice rink in the winter.
Customer reviews: -During winter, the fountain area is converted into an public ice rink and is free if you bring your own skates. You also have the option to rent skates for a fee. It gets a bit busy during the weekend but the space is enough for everyone to enjoy the ice. The surface gets a bit rough with all the skaters but it's still a fun winter activity for the whole family. The area is quiet picturesque and you can take some nice picture specially at night when the Toronto sign is lit up in the dark.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      -Very nice. There is a lot going on, especially in the evenings. In winter there is an ice rink, which is free - only rent skates for a fee. It is nice to sit by the pool in the evening and enjoy the view of the square. It can be quite crowded on holidays and vacations. The main attraction are the letters TORONTO, which also light up at night. Wonderful place to take a photo.

Name: Harvey's
About information: Harvey's is a fast food restaurant chain operating in Canada, with locations in every province except British Columbia. It serves hamburgers, poutine, hot dogs, french fries, onion rings, and other traditional Canadian fast-food fare.
Customer reviews:
-Was so looking forward to this. But it was nowhere close compared to South St. and Priest.
-Came for 2 Jr chicken burgers. Tasted great, fresh veggies. Great healthy meal.

Each burger had 1 sauce: Garlic mayo and Harv sauce. Note that I don't like Harv sauce, so future get another sauce, like Ranch or any new sauces they have.

Name: Pizzeria Libretto - University
About information: Wood-fired Neapolitan-style pizzas made with simple ingredients & served in a bustling space.
Customer reviews: -Great pizza, great gnocchi, great ambiance and decent service! The chili oil was very flavorful. The portion of the gnocchi is quite less and the taste is so creamy and flavorful that it leaves you wanting for more. We had a great time here and it exceeded our expectations. Usually Za is our go to for pizza in downtown but now we added Libretto to our list. Can't wait to go back and try more pizzas and the appetizer gnocchi.                                                                                                                                                                 -Absolutely incredible food and stellar service!! They were able to rush my order so I could make it to my show. The staff were incredibly kind, patient and attentive. I cannot rave about them enough. I had the gorgonzola gnocchi and it was simply divine. I had cleaned my plate in 10 minutes, that’s how good it was. If you need some delicious food while you’re downtown, you should definitely go here!

Name: Moxies Toronto Downtown Restaurant
About information: Open for dine-in, pick-up, take-out & delivery. Moxies restaurant is a contemporary casual restaurant offering a globally inspired menu and hand crafted cocktails in a vibrant and interactive atmosphere.
Customer reviews: -Came here for desert our server was very kind and attentive. The place looked good and up scale the brownie was tasty. There is no free parking which is a downside.                                                                                                                                                                  -We went for lunch during the workday. Our food came quick, it was excellent, but a bit overpriced. The place was very busy but not too loud. Great spot for a nice lunch during the day. I got the tofu lettuce wraps, and my friends liked what they got as well.

Name: Basil Box
About information: Basil Box reintroduces Asian cuisine to the North American market in an authentic and healthy way, to satisfy both your cravings and your conscience. You don't need more time to eat right: you can build your box in minutes, knowing that you're doing right by your mind and your body.
Customer reviews:
-Right in the heart of downtown Toronto, Basil Box is a great option whenever I want a meal that is healthy, not heavy, and affordable.

I had the chance to try their MVB- most valuable boxes. These amerprotein and fibre packed boxes at a great price. In addition, you also get a free Iced Tea with the purchase of an MVB. You get the choice of Signature Chicken, Healthy Steak, and Yuzu Tofu. The Yuan Tofu was so flavourful and the Healthy Steak was savoury and delicious. The Iced Teas paired perfectly with the MVBs.  The spring rolls were surprisingly not oily and extra crispy. Last but not least, the the Bahn Mi fries were superb.

Can't wait to come back for some more!                                                                                                                                                                 -Just ordered a lovely meal here! I got the lemongrass chicken with rice and peanut sauce. The chicken was juicy and not overcooked, rice was great, peanut sauce was delish. I’ll be ordered from here again. Portions are great sizes too!

Name: Banh Mi Boys
About information: Asian-inspired subs, sandwiches, tacos & steamed buns spiced to order in a snug & lively location.
Customer reviews: -We got the kimchi fries and kalbi beef tacos. The cashiers was really nice and the food did not take too long to be ready. The kimchi fries were good as well as the tacos. The beef was tender and was not hard to work through. Flavour for both was definitely there and would go back if I was in the area!                                                          -Solid bahn mi - the grilled pork was juicy and the sauce complimented the flavours nicely. They also had a generous amount of the pickled carrot radish and cucumber.

Name: Rolltation Sushi Burrito
About information: Asian inspired fast casual restaurant!
Customer reviews: -Wonderful culinary experience in downtown Toronto, steps away from Eaton Centre. We ordered Umami Poke Bowl, California poke bowl and wasabi tuna poke bowl. What a treat for tastebuds, different textures, flavors, spice. Supremely satisfying and filling comfort food. Will definitely visit again!                                                                                                                                                                     -Bowls and burritos are delicious. Service is fast, and there are a decent amount of tables, but it gets busy during peak meal hours.

Name: Royal Oak Inn
About information:
In the residential area of Cabbage Town, this low-key hotel in a remodeled Victorian-style building is a 4-minute walk from casual dining and a 3-minute streetcar ride from Ryerson University.
Simple rooms with hardwood floors and en suite bathrooms feature basic furnishings and retro-modern decor including flat-screen TVs with cable channels, radios and free WiFi.
Continental breakfast is complimentary.
Customer reviews: -Other then the bed being comfortable, it was not the cleanest and it was very noisy the whole night through. Pretty sketchy area. Not comforting for a girl travelling solo. I’m an experienced traveller and not scared easily. This one night stay wasn’t pleasant at all.                                                                                                                                 -A perfectly fine place to stay for cheap! Clean with good service. Like the reviews say, it's a little noisy, and the area isn't great. No hidden fees or tricks, and the price is great

Name: The Saint James Hotel, Ascend Hotel Collection
About information:
A 3-minute walk from College subway station, this straightforward redbrick hotel is also a 6-minute walk from the Ed Mirvish Theatre and 2.6 km from the CN Tower.
The modern rooms feature free Wi-Fi, 42-inch flat-screen TVs and pull-out sofas. All rooms come with minifridges, microwaves and coffeemakers.
Guests receive complimentary passes to a nearby fitness centre. There's also a business centre.
Customer reviews: -This newly renovated hotel is quite nice. Lovely room; modern furnishings. The desk staff are very helpful & the breakfast is wonderful - fresh/healthy/substantial. Inexpensive parking arrangement. The only negative is the small bathroom with a small sink & little room for toiletries.                                      -Great location on a relatively quiet street but within walking distance of many restaurants and shops. Rooms were large, clean, and modern. Bed was very, very comfortable. Breakfast downstairs was included and was your choice of breakfast wrap and choice of oatmeal. Bathrooms were of good size, with modern fixtures and rainforest shower head. I would definitely stay here again.

Name: Sonder The Wellesley
About information:
Set in a Victorian mansion, this elegant boutique hotel is across from the Wellesley subway platform and 1 km from the Mars Discovery District.
The antiques-furnished rooms feature period details and modern amenities like flat-screen TVs and individual climate controls, in addition to free WiFi. Upgraded rooms add high ceilings.
Luggage storage can be arranged.
Customer reviews: -Easy access to a simple but affordable hotel right at the metro station. Full access to Netflix etc and clean. The bed was very confortable. The outside looks a bit like a spooky manor but inside it’s all modern and well designed. Everything is available.                         -I love staying here, location is great, the rooms are cozy. This just time my room was freezing cold because there heater wasn't working. The unfortunate part I contacted them but I didn't get any response or acknowledgement, which was really disappointing. I wanted to go buy a space heater but was only there for two nights, they should really improve their customer service.

Name: Cambridge Suites Toronto
About information:
Set among the shops and restaurants of Downtown, this upscale, all-suite hotel is a 3-minute walk from the Toronto Eaton Centre mall and 7 minutes' stroll from lively Yonge-Dundas Square.
The warm suites offer microwaves, minifridges and coffeemakers, plus separate sitting areas and flat-screens. Wi-Fi is free. Upgraded suites add free breakfast, pillow-top beds and high-thread-count sheets, plus whirlpool tubs and pull-out sofas. Some have kitchenettes and split levels.
Amenities include a rooftop exercise room, a business centre and a stylish restaurant.
Customer reviews:
-I don’t usually leave reviews but I can’t help but rate this hotel a 10/10. I’m beyond impressed by everything. The rooms are HUGE and kept very clean. The location is wonderful, you’re so close to everything if you choose to stay here. The price is also something you can’t beat. I’m so impressed and will be staying here the next time I come to Toronto. I noticed at night they have security standing by the door and you can’t enter after a certain time of the evening without swiping your room key, which made me feel extremely safe and secure. Love this place and can’t wait to be back!!                                -With clean rooms and comfortable beds. I highly recommend this hotel.
It's a short walk to the nearest subway station so getting around is nice and easy.
Cannot stress enough how much I enjoyed the fact that the room was clean and comfortable.

Name: Econo Lodge Inn & Suites Downtown
About information:
This budget hotel is 1.8 km from the Four Seasons Centre and 2.8 km from the CN Tower.
Straightforward rooms feature desks, free WiFi and TVs. Upgraded rooms include whirlpool tubs, minifridges and microwaves. Suites offer 2 levels and separate living rooms.
Amenities include complimentary continental breakfast and a business center.
Customer reviews: -This is a good centrally located hotel that is very clean and very well priced for its location. I know it has a reputation, but stayed here for one nite and never experienced anything out of the ordinary. The hotel itself is very clean and the rooms the same. Again, you could pay the high end cost for a more reputable hotel, but if you want prime location (walking distance to everything downtown) and reasonably priced as I said, this is the go to hotel!!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            -This hotel was a in a great location, friendly staff. Breakfast was not good at all cereal and toast, but did have complimentary coffee 24/7. Room was clean and modern although the halls do have old carpet and smell a little off. Bathrooms were really clean and remodeled overall good value.

Name: Hampton Inn & Suites by Hilton Toronto Downtown
About information: Enjoy recreational amenities such as a fitness center and bicycles to rent. Additional amenities at this hotel include complimentary wireless internet access, concierge services, and wedding services.
Customer reviews: -Hotel was really great. The whole hotel seems to have been recently renovated and the rooms are big and clean. Hotel staff was very helpful and were always happy to help! The included breakfast is way ahead of most hotels for a complimentary breakfast. Hot food and a good selection. The location is perfect, less than 10 minutes from the subway and next to a streetcar stop. Hotel is almost in the heart of downtown so it's easy to come and go as you want during the day. I recommend this place and would definitely like to go back again!                     -Hotel is centrally located about 15 minute walk from Yonge street. I arrived late evening and was greeted by friendly reception staff. Received a complimentary upgrade and some free snacks for being a gold member. Room was huge and comfortable. Breakfast was nice, normal standard for a Hampton.

Name: Toronto Metropolitan University Community Park
About information: Small public university campus park with an ice rink from November to February & some benches.
Customer reviews: -A good place to sit around and breathe in fresh oxygen in summer. You can do walks around the guad for exercise. There is also the university gym underground.                                                                                -I just discovered they have bouldering here and came for the first time. It wasn't very busy around 6 pm but gradually became more packed. Lots of friendly folks and you can boulder late with the lights from the surrounding buildings. You'll need to bring your own crash pad of course.

Name: Royal Ontario Museum
About information: Sprawling natural history & world cultures galleries, plus dinosaur fossil skeletons.
Customer reviews: -Very cool so many things to look at it’s almost overwhelming! I recommend spending 3-4hours here so you can see everything, they have a great little cafe on the main floor and all of the staff were very nice and helpful. I am very interested in the provenance for the totem poles that go throughout the main staircase and wether or not they have came here ethically or if they are a stolen colonial souvenir from the West Coast, any information would be lovely and most appreciated!                                                                        -One of the best museum I ever visited. Clean and organized and friendly staff. Different sections with a complete guide. Only concern is parking space specially on the weekends. I highly recommend this place

Name: Captive Escape Rooms Downtown Toronto
About information: You know the deal. You and your friends are going to be locked in Toronto's most realistic escape room for 45 minutes, and it's going to take all of your courage and cunning to escape!
Customer reviews: -Great time. Went to the captive escape rooms with my work team and we did the Blind Tiger room. Puzzles were fun and engaging. Staff is great and very kind.                                                                             -I had an incredible experience at Captive Escape Room in downtown Toronto. Doug, our guide, was instrumental in making it memorable. His assistance was invaluable, offering us extra time and patiently handling all the hints we required. Doug's dedication and helpfulness truly enhanced our escape room adventure. Highly recommend!

Name: Casa Loma Escape Rooms
About information: The Casa Loma Escape Rooms feature five immersive games with live actors, perfect for a night out with friends and family at Toronto's majestic castle.
Customer reviews: -We did the Murdock Mystery Escape Room. We've never done an escape room so really didn't know what to expect. Loved it, well done Casa Loma! The time slot we chose we were the only 2, so it did make things alittle more difficult. We did get some help from the actors, and after the hour, we were able to reflect on what we missed. Actors are very engaging, great job. Anyone considering buying tickets, do it!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             -So much fun! The character interacting with you adds another level to an already amazing escape room!  We did Station M with 12 people, definitely one of the harder ones we’ve done. But we escaped with a few seconds to spare!

Name: Levelup Virtual Reality (VR) Arcade
About information: Contemporary arcade featuring over 80 different virtual reality games for groups & individuals.
Customer reviews: -This is a new and unique experience for kids and adults alike! Plenty of room for multiple groups to all play at the same time. The customer service was fantastic as the employees were regularly coming around to check on the players and were there instantly whenever someone pressed the help button  to walk them through a game or using the equipment. Will definitely come back soon!                     -Great VR location and setup.  Very spacious and well kept.  Layout is efficient and all equipment is cleaned before/after use.  Staff are monitoring and can help out without even needing to call for help.  Brought my kids (smallest was 8 years old), and had games that they enjoyed.  No hesitation in recommending Levelup.  The staff were friendly and helpful.  Washrooms were clean and well kept.  Good job! A+

Name: Mackenzie House
About information: 19th-century row house museum dedicated to historic politician & publisher William Lyon Mackenzie.
Customer reviews: -The print shop is beautiful. Unfortunately, aside from that room, the house is empty right now. The staff was very nice and shared very interesting facts about Toronto. They do organize workshops and events that I think are worth checking out. Overall, I enjoyed my time at the museum. I would definitely recommend a 1-hour visit!                                                                                                                                                                                                                            -This is a wonderful little museum dedicated to Toronto's first mayor and the Grandfather of Willian Lyon Mackenzie King. The house is in poor shape due to a flood, but the staff do a great job describing how the house used to look. The print shop is very interesting.

Name: Spring Sushi Toronto (4th Floor)
About information: Brightly lit, spacious place for Japanese & Thai cuisine, with a patio & touch-screen food ordering.
Customer reviews: -Maybe 3 1/2 stars. The food was decent, fresh, and we got a great table by the window in the corner overlooking the square. I’ve had equally good all you can eat (the place on Dundas near Chestnut) but less slick and less expensive than this place. Not sure I liked the iPad ordering thing, and the table service was good but like other reviewers I got snotty vibes from the hostess desk when we got in.                                                                     -Modern all you can eat Japanese restaurant that uses a tablet as a menu and to order from.  Lots of items to choose from including specialty items for an added cost.  Good place to take family.

Name: Mogouyan Hand Pulled Noodle
About information: Skewers, housemade noodle dishes & other classic Chinese fare in a relaxed restaurant with delivery.
Customer reviews: -We went for dinner on a Tuesday night and got a booth for 2 immediately. The interior was bigger than we expected. We ordered $13.5 regular classic beef noodles and $15.95 braised beef noodles. The dishes were on par with the best we've had before. The noodle texture was great, and the portion was large with a good amount of beef and radish. My only few nitpicks are that one of the menus was worn out to the point that we couldn't read some parts, and the classic beef was very soft and fell apart easily. Note that the spice levels are quite mild, even with a mediocre spice tolerance (the server said kids are fine with 1 pepper spice level)                                                                                                                                                       -The noodles were excellent and reasonably priced! I also enjoyed my Northern China Lights cocktail, although it was quite pricey. There was a bit of a line for dinner, but the line moved relatively quickly so it wasn't a big deal. I'll be back again when I'm craving hand pulled noodles in the area.

Name: Trattoria Mercatto
About information: Chic, upmarket Italian place featuring elevated Italian cuisine & an expansive wine list.
Customer reviews: -I have been coming here for years when visiting in Toronto, the food and service have been always great, and perfect location after some shopping. Very grateful for the hostess to notice my mom was walking with a walking stick, she immediately change our table to the lower floor to avoid the climbing. Simply Thank you.                                                                                                                                                                                            -Amazing food and the olive oil to melt in. I asked my amazing server to let me have the rest of my olive oil, and he generously wrapped them for me. I literally ate them with baguette the next day. Besides the great food, definitely try their desserts. They're so good.

Name: Red Lobster
About information: Lively chain restaurant serving American seafood standards amid New England-themed decor.
Customer reviews:
-It was our first time at Red lobster and we got the all you can eat shrimp which was amazing! Our favourites were the garlic butter shrimp and the grilled shrimp skewer with fresh lemon. The garlic butter shrimp was very flavourful and always served hot and I definitely suggest trying it.

The island jumbo coconut shrimp was nice and had a slightly sweet taste to it. The popcorn shrimp and Walt’s favorite shrimp were alright only because the breading didn’t add any flavour and the oil it was prepared in made it taste a bit bitter. I wouldn’t get those two options again.

The service was great and our waitress was very friendly :) I would definitely come back just for the garlic butter shrimp and their cheddar bay biscuits!                                                                                                   -Service and food preparation were on point at this location!

It's been years since my partner and I had red lobster so we decided to pop in and try their endless shrimp. Food was prepared well, portions were good, and value is excellent. Tastes and flavours were just as I remembered, basically butter and salt, but expectations were met and everything was cooked well.

Service was absolutely amazing and our server Sherif went above an beyond to be accommodating and ensure we were well taken care of. Definitely made our experience extra enjoyable and would be back strictly because of the service.

While there's many better options for seafood across the city, Red Lobster holds that iconic family seafood restaurant status and this location holds up well. Great for a date or family outing, we'll definitely be back when craving some buttery biscuits and endless shrimp!

Name: Grillies (Dundas & Jarvis)
About information: Looking for a quick bite or planning a get together, look no further, we have got you covered with delicious food like we have been doing for others for many years now.
Customer reviews:
-Absolute steal for your money. The burgers are top 5 in the city for less than $10 each. All of the employees are so nice and hard working. Khushi, Sanish, Vishal are incredible people and definitely deserve raises. They catered to my every need and I’m so relieved every time I see them. I’ve seen them able to handle a rush and get every order perfect. On top of that they made great conversation and made the whole experience one worth telling others about. 12/10 definitely recommend. I’m here at LEAST once every week - if not for the great food, but the amazing customer service. Plus, the music is always on point. The place itself is always clean and the orders are dished out QUICK.
Thank you grillies for always being there for me (open 24hrs).                                                                                                                                                                  -In 35 years of eating food, this place makes the best burgers in the world. 10/10. Almost made me cry its that good. Double cheeseburger, sweet bbq sauce, cheddar, and the onion rings are the best ive ever had.

Name: Hotel Victoria
About information:
Dating from 1909, this elegant hotel is a 2-minute walk from King Station subway stop, a 7-minute walk from St. Lawrence Market and 2 km from the landmark CN Tower.
Sleek rooms with hardwood floors and pillow-top mattresses offer free Wi-Fi, and flat-screen TVs with premium cable channels, plus coffeemakers. Upgraded rooms add smart TVs and minifridges.
An airy, casual restaurant with high ceilings offers breakfast and lunch for a fee.
Customer reviews: -Very nice, no frills hotel. It's in a perfect location for my weekend. The staff are very friendly and do their job well. The one lady named Aisha has stood out like a jem. Aisha was sincere, kind, and went out of her way to make us feel welcome and was so accommodating. She is an amazing person, and she made this a nice experience for my son and I, so thanks                                                                                                                                                                          -Stayed here for a Leafs game. We took the Go Train to Union Station and it was literally around the corner, location is perfect. Room is very small just a bed a bathroom but that’s all we needed, and for the price point it was well worth it. Hot water for shower worked before we left for the game, then tried to have a shower when we got back from the game and no hot water. Would definitely come back as the location was great and best price we found.

Name: The Ivy At Verity
About information:
In a converted 1850s chocolate factory in the Queen Street East District, this elegant boutique hotel inspired by classic European style is a 9-minute walk from Old City Hall and a 7-minute light-rail ride from the Canadian Opera Company's performing arts centre.
The 4 luxe rooms mixing vintage-style and contemporary decor with high-end furnishings feature balconies overlooking a 19th-century courtyard, flat-screen TVs, Blu-ray players and Wi-Fi.
A contemporary restaurant serves international cuisine in a chic dining room and a garden. A colourful lounge serves afternoon tea and light dinners. In-room spa services have a surcharge.
Customer reviews:
-What a wonderful Hotel!  This hotel has a small number of rooms and they are booked months in advance.  The Hotel is  rather discreet from the street, but once inside it is absolutely beautiful.  Nicely decorated with a wonderful collection of a variety of art.  The room was large and the bathroom is to die for.  The bathroom is larger than some hotel rooms I have been in.  The accommodations are outstanding with top of the line accoutrements. Everything was better than First Class.  The staff is very accommodating and George the concierge and Cecile the manager made sure that everything was taken care of.  They have numerous meeting rooms, outdoor patios both private for the rooms and a large one able to take care of several groups.  Breakfast (Continental) was excellent.  Next time in Toronto I hope I know long enough in advance to be able to reserve a room at the Ivy!  I would give them more than 5 stars.                                                                                                                                     -Location pretty central, just a few blocks from Yonge. Lovely spacious rooms, just one of four at the Verity, each with gigantic bathrooms. Shower and soaking tub includes with a selection of bath salts. Complimentary breakfast was delicious and a very special touch! Attentive kind staff at the front desk. Also visited the spa for a circuit- complete with an ozonated pool, whirlpool, ir sauna and steam room. Plenty of quiet nooks to relax and unwind. Highly recommend for a weekend getaway to pamper yourself!
If there was anything to add, it would be to add some eucalyptus essence for the steam room!

Name: Canada Suites
About information:
Set a 5-minute walk from College Station subway stop, this modern all-suite hotel is set in a high-rise building. It's an 11-minute walk from Downtown, and 1.3 km from the University of Toronto.
The casual, apartment-style suites offer kitchens, fireplaces and balconies, as well as flat-screen TVs, iPod docks and washer/dryers. Wi-Fi is free.
There's a relaxed Italian eatery, plus a terrace with seating. Other amenities include an indoor pool and a hot tub, plus a gym and a convenience store.
Customer reviews:
-Excellent building , Quiet, clean with excellent view, Great walking access to all areas of downtown Toronto. Stayed for 9 nights with no issues with anything. Canada suites were very friendly and helpful , handled everything remotely and met us in lobby as agreed . Would recommend as good value and will use again in future.
Everett.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                -Everything was excellent during our staying in the apt. Location is fantastic. Staff was friendly and attentive. Spacious rooms, beds super comfy and the kitchen is equipped with everything needed.

Name: The Omni King Edward Hotel
About information:
Dating from 1903, this posh hotel in Downtown is a 2-minute walk from King subway station, 16 minutes' walk from the Metro Toronto Convention Centre, and an 11-minute walk from shopping at the Toronto Eaton Centre.
Elegant rooms have flat-screens, iPod docks and Wi-Fi (fee), plus Keurig coffeemakers. Upgraded rooms add sitting areas. Suites offer living rooms; an upgraded suite features 2 fireplaces, a kitchen and a dining area. Club-level quarters have access to a lounge with free breakfast. Room service is offered 24/7.
There's a polished restaurant and a swanky bar, as well as a spa, a fitness centre and meeting space. Parking is available.
Customer reviews:
-What an amazing hotel. From the time we pulled up to the door to the time we left the service was impeccable.  Doormen, reception and all the other staff...so attentive, caring and friendly.
The Consort Bar was comfortable with a great vibe. Food was very good. Service was also excellent. A special thank you to Valentina. It's as though she knew what we needed before we asked.  Lovely lady and great server. I have mobility issues and everyone went out of their way to help me.
The suite was clean and nicely appointed.  Bed and pillows comfortable.  If I had one thing that I would change...I would ensure a south facing room. The noise from the street cars was very loud and disturbing.  That said...we will definitely be back.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                -This was my first time staying at the King Edward and it definitely won't be my last! I had the best hotel service from Madeleine and Brian who were so courteous and helpful and took my stay from a 5/5 to 6/5! The rooms were plush and beautiful and super spacious (love the tall ceilings too). I also had the chance to go to the Mokara Spa and had such a delightful experience there too, and it's amazing to stay in a hotel where there's a full service spa. I'd encourage anyone when they stay here to go on a walk of the hotel, there's so much rich history here. And the best part? The cost was surprisingly reasonable given the outstanding service and heritage/beauty of the hotel. Thank you King Eddy!

Name: The St. Regis Toronto
About information:
On a bustling street and 5 minutes by foot from the nearest subway station, this luxury high-rise hotel is 5 minutes’ walk from shopping at the Toronto Eaton Centre and 17 minutes’ walk from the landmark CN Tower.
Accommodations range from plush rooms with city views to chic 2-bedroom suites with kitchens, living rooms and 8-seat dining tables. All feature flat-screen TVs and free Wi-Fi, as well as minibars, tea and coffeemakers, and safes. Room service is offered 24/7.
Amenities include a fine-dining restaurant, a posh lobby lounge and a spa. There’s also an indoor pool, a hot tub and a gym, plus 14 event rooms and parking (fee).
Customer reviews: -Fabulous rooms, excellent service and a wonderful cocktail lounge in the main lobby. Location was excellent as well. Rooms were extremely clean and modern. When checking in to the hotel, look for Mark. He is extremely professional, kind and goes above and beyond. Had the pleasure of dealing with on both our visits. Look forward to our next stay at the St. Regis Toronto.                                                          -Absolutely perfect in every area. 2nd to none, St Regis is our favorite place to stay in Toronto. The do not miss in every area from knowing your name upon entry, offering directions or water when through the lobby, smiling and greeting 24/7 with a wave and words to the fresh clean look and smell of every part of the hotel. They obviously hit on all major places but they are aet apart with the little things. The rooms are outstanding in design and detail. Turn down service to products in room are spot on. We have stayed Everywhere and many yes are excellent but the St Regis is above excellence.

Name: The Distillery Historic District
About information: A collection of boutiques, galleries, cafes & restaurants takes the place of a former distillery.
Customer reviews: -I've travelled to Toronto from Saskatoon 20+ times and this was my first time visiting the Distillery District. I know it's renowned for its Christmas Market but I went in February, on a quiet Monday afternoon. It's a beautiful little area, lined with cobblestone streets and historic buildings. The buildings are now filled with independent boutiques and eating places. There are lots of unique spots for photo ops. I wouldn't rank this as a must-do/must-see for travellers outside of the holiday season but if you have time to just stroll around and/or enjoy shopping at unique independent boutiques, the Distillery District has a beautiful vibe.                                          -Good place to meet friends and walk around.  Winter time is somewhat empty UNLESS you go during the light show is for a limited time so check the schedule.  The shopkeepers are friendly and make you feel welcome.

Name: Toronto Old City Hall
About information: Built in 1899, this Richardsonian romanesque civic building showcases a clock tower & gargoyles.
Customer reviews:
-This historic building was completed  in 1899 after 11 years under construction. The Romanesque-style architectural design of the interior and exterior has animal and human cravings throughout the building are magnificent. The prominent clock tower is still in good working condition. This landmark is a must see heritage site.

The public can still go into 60 Queen Street for minor traffic offences. The city is still hearing matters there until they move to Front and the Esplanade while that courthouse is built.                                                                                                                                                                                                                              -The exterior of this grand historic building, constructed in Romanesque style in 1889 (completed in 1899), with a prominent clock tower, is impressive and one can spend a good deal of time admiring the details of its design. The building appeared to be locked, but we pushed open a heavy door to discover that it was indeed open. There were strict security procedures in order to enter, as the building now operates as a court house - the largest and busiest in all of Canada. The magnificent interior with its mosaic floor, columns, gargoyles, old elevator shaft, caricatures of Councillors, staircase and stained glass window was well worth a visit.

Name: Toronto Island Park
About information: Scenic vistas of the Toronto skyline are a main attraction at this lush, grassy recreation area.
Customer reviews: -It is possible to walk the full length of the Islands, however, a bicycle is highly recommended for getting around more quickly. This enables one to explore the 3 main islands: Ward Island with its quaint and picturesque residences, Centre Island which is the entertainment hub and Hanlon Island, known for being natural. One can also bike across the connecting bridges to some of the smaller islands. There is something for everyone - stunning iconic views of the Toronto skyline, beaches, Centreville Amusement Park, boating, picnic areas, historic lighthouse, to name a few. Also cafes and restaurants, toilets and bike rental. We rented our bikes on the mainland and took them across on the ferry. This allowed us to explore further once we returned to the mainland, before handing our bikes back.                                                                                                                                                                                                                            -This is one of the best parks in town for a quick getaway trip. Easily accessible from the heart of downtown Toronto, It has a great view of the skyline, areas where you can watch the sunset, loads of picnic area, multilple beaches, bike rentals, and much more to do! It does get very crowded in summers. The view does not get old, though!

Name: High Park
About information: Sprawling park with hiking trails, a zoo, sports fields & a large children's playground.
Customer reviews:
-I recently visited the park, and it exceeded my expectations in every way. The vast open spaces allowed for serene walks, while the diverse terrains added an adventurous touch. The small zoo was a delightful surprise, offering a charming variety of animals. The lakes added tranquility, making it a perfect spot for picnics. A truly immersive experience that caters to all ages and interests.
Just that carry some food and snacks with you, because once you enter, there is no place to eat, just one or two eateries, but most of the times it is close.                                                                                                     -I absolutely love this park. It's a large park with tall wide trees and unleashed areas for dogs to run free. Long wide paths to walk, jog, and bike ride. There's a sports area as well as a performance stage for entertainment. You'll see squirrels and cute chipmunks running around. There's also a little zoo on the grounds, and it's gorgeous in the fall.

Name: St. Lawrence Market
About information: Spacious market with 100+ vendors, bakers, butchers & artisans, with produce & antiques on weekends.
Customer reviews:
-First-time visitors to St. Lawrence Market on weekends will find it moderately crowded with a 60s spirit, offering a plethora of unique items from around the world, as well as organic and Ontario-grown produce, meat, veggies, souvenirs, and kitchen supplies. You are sure to find something that captures your heart. Additionally, I was impressed to discover the second floor for the first time, having missed it on prior visits. It’s definitely worth checking out!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                -I had a great experience at St. Lawrence Market. It's a hub of fresh food, bakeries, and fruits, all of excellent quality. The market has a farm market vibe, although being in the core of downtown, it's understandably a bit more expensive.

I particularly enjoyed the variety of offerings. However, it's worth noting that some food stores within the market only accept cash, so it's a good idea to bring some with you. Despite this minor inconvenience, the overall atmosphere and the quality of the goods make it a worthwhile visit. Highly recommended for those looking for a diverse and fresh food market experience in the heart of the city.
